explanation:
To determine if any part of OS_CondVarBroadcast is statically unreachable you must know the semantics and declarations of the functions/macros/constants used and any test-harness instrumentation that might alter control flow:

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: The branch condition (if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)) depends entirely on what this function can return and whether it may have side-effects (e.g. longjmp, noreturn). You need its prototype/implementation/specification to know whether the if-body can ever be executed or is always/never taken.

- OS_SUCCESS: The value and definition of this macro/enum member is required to evaluate the conditional expression; if OS_SUCCESS equals a constant that makes the comparison always true/false, the if-block would be unreachable.

- OS_CondVarBroadcast_Impl: The call inside the if assigns its return to return_code. You must know its prototype and attributes (e.g. does it have a noreturn attribute, or does it always abort/loop) to determine whether subsequent code (the final return) can be reached.

- OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE and OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR: These constants are passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById; in some implementations they might affect OS_ObjectIdGetById behavior (for example cause it to always fail/succeed). Their definitions are needed to fully evaluate reachability of the branch.

- OS_object_token_t: The type of token is needed to ensure the &token argument is valid and that any type-specific semantics (e.g. if it is a macro with side-effects) do not introduce unreachable code. Also needed to inspect any attributes that could affect calling conventions.

- osal_id_t and int32: The integer and id typedefs are needed to confirm types used in the function signature and local variable behavior (e.g. if int32 is defined as a type with attributes that affect control flow analysis).

- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: The static call graph shows these unit-test/stub-related symbols as callees of OS_CondVarBroadcast (likely injected by test macros). Their semantics can alter control flow (e.g. register handlers that may replace the behavior of OS_ObjectIdGetById or OS_CondVarBroadcast_Impl, or macros that expand to control-flow constructs). To be sure no code in OS_CondVarBroadcast is made unreachable by test-harness instrumentation, their definitions/behaviors must be known.

In summary, the above symbols provide the necessary declarations/behaviors to decide whether the conditional and the subsequent call/return in OS_CondVarBroadcast can ever be executed; without them you cannot soundly conclude whether any part of the function is unreachable per MISRA C.
